Situation1: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A severe hurricane has left hundreds of people homeless in the community, and the mayor has asked the nun to help organize a major relief effort.
Story: The shrill ring of my work phone cut through the quiet of the convent’s common room. I glanced at the screen—urgent: main production unit down, sensor errors, thirty minutes and counting. My mind immediately began mapping out possible causes, the familiar logic of diagnostics kicking in. But before I could respond, Sister Agnes burst in, her face pale. “The mayor is here. He needs you. The hurricane’s left so many without homes. He says you’re the only one who can organize the relief effort.” My heart twisted. As a nun, I was expected to serve, to be present for those in need, especially now, when the community was reeling. Yet, as a machine repairer, I knew the factory’s halt meant lost wages for dozens of families—families who might soon need that very relief. Both roles demanded my full attention, both urgent, both vital. I felt torn, the weight of expectation pressing from all sides, my mind racing as I stood between the mayor and my ringing phone, unable to move.
